claim: No citizen of San Antonio voted for Boris Johnson.

supporting.text: Boris Johnson is the former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, and San Antonio is a city in the United States, where only U.S. citizens can vote in local and national elections.

attacks.text: Boris Johnson is the former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, and San Antonio is a city in the United States, where only U.S. citizens can vote in local and national elections.
Some U.S. citizens may hold dual citizenship with the U.K. and could have voted for Boris Johnson in U.K. elections.
U.K. elections require physical presence or specific absentee voting procedures, making it unlikely for San Antonio residents to participate.
The claim specifies 'no citizen,' which is an absolute statement and could be disproven by a single counterexample.
There is no documented evidence of any San Antonio citizen voting for Boris Johnson.

supporting.text: U.S. citizens, including those in San Antonio, do not participate in U.K. general elections, which are restricted to British citizens and eligible Commonwealth citizens.

attacks.text: U.S. citizens, including those in San Antonio, do not participate in U.K. general elections, which are restricted to British citizens and eligible Commonwealth citizens.
Some U.S. citizens may hold dual citizenship with the U.K. or a Commonwealth country, allowing them to vote in U.K. elections.
Dual citizens from San Antonio voting in U.K. elections would be extremely rare and statistically negligible.
The claim does not specify a time frame, and historical records might show exceptions if San Antonio had British expatriates in the past.
Historical British expatriates in San Antonio voting in U.K. elections would still not qualify as 'citizens of San Antonio' in the modern sense.

supporting.text: Voting in U.K. elections requires registration in the U.K., which is not accessible to residents of San Antonio unless they hold British citizenship and meet residency requirements.

attacks.text: Voting in U.K. elections requires registration in the U.K., which is not accessible to residents of San Antonio unless they hold British citizenship and meet residency requirements.
Some residents of San Antonio may hold dual citizenship (U.S. and U.K.) and meet U.K. residency requirements, enabling them to vote for Boris Johnson.
The number of San Antonio residents with dual U.S.-U.K. citizenship and U.K. residency is statistically negligible, making the claim effectively true.
U.K. election laws allow overseas British citizens to vote in U.K. elections regardless of their current residency, provided they register as overseas voters.
Registering as an overseas voter requires prior U.K. residency, which most San Antonio residents lack unless they previously lived in the U.K.

supporting.text: There is no legal mechanism for citizens of San Antonio to vote in U.K. elections, as electoral systems are sovereign and do not allow foreign participation.

attacks.text: There is no legal mechanism for citizens of San Antonio to vote in U.K. elections, as electoral systems are sovereign and do not allow foreign participation.
Some citizens of San Antonio may hold dual U.K. citizenship, allowing them to vote in U.K. elections.
Dual citizenship is rare, and the number of San Antonio residents with U.K. citizenship is statistically negligible.
U.K. electoral laws have exceptions for certain Commonwealth citizens, who might include residents of San Antonio.
Commonwealth citizens eligible to vote in U.K. elections must be resident in the U.K., excluding San Antonio residents.
